ResponsesInList.Title: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: We see numerous discussions in this forum (and elsewhere) around this topic. In simple terms the question is " Should we use the H5P plugin, or use the H5P integration that now exists in Moodle Core? " The core H5P module is the one that belongs to the core H5P, which has a BLUE icon in Moodle, from the Moodle HQ. HVP module (or just HVP) refers to https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_hvp , and has a BLACK icon in Moodle, and this is an additional plug-in from the developers at h5p.org. There is an official migration tool from Moodle HQ: https://moodle.org/plugins/tool_migratehvp2h5p . The answer to "Which to use?" is not entirely simple, and in fact may be different for different Moodle sites. However, H5P recently released an important statement on H5P.org [ https://h5p.org/moodle-plugin-vs-moodle-core-vs-h5p-com ] ALSO note that since this thread was initially started the status of H5P.com is now a commercial option. Please do read the full ¬†press release (it's not too long) but here is the summary: Comparison of the three options [for Moodle users/sites] The H5P Plugin (recommended) Includes the full version of H5P including the H5P Hub, making it compatible with the OER Hub and future versions of H5P. Maintained by the H5P Core Team. Available as a plugin on Moodle.org, allowing for self-hosting and managing of the H5P content. H5P.com (recommended) The best version of H5P delivered as a service; hosted and supported by the H5P Core Team, integrates via LTI . Will soon include premium features allowing for a better authoring experience and several unique H5P dimensions that need special server side technologies to work. Includes the full version of H5P including the H5P Hub, making it compatible with the OER Hub and future versions of H5P. This is a paid service, so if you use H5P.com you also help fund the development of H5P. The Moodle core integration Partial integration of H5P as an optional feature in Moodle core, developed and maintained by Moodle HQ. Offers a tighter integration with Moodle and the Moodle Mobile App. We currently do not know if and when a full integration of H5P will be in place. So what does this mean in the real world? ¬†I suggest... If your site is not currently using the H5P plugin, and you will be upgrading to Moodle 3.9, use the core functionality. Even though there are issues, and maybe some missing H5P features, the core H5P functionality is likely to get better in Moodle 4.0 released next year. If H5P is not a big part of your plans, if it's being used a little bit, or just here and there, and it's not critical, then you should probably just use the H5P in core Moodle. However, if H5P is a major part of your Moodle site already, and you see H5P as a critical and central part of your e-learning within Moodle, then you may want to continue to use the H5P plugin, and disable the core H5P functionality within Moodle (it would be confusing to have two ways of adding and managing H5P). It's also important to note that if you are linking your Moodle site to H5P.com (paid service) the LTI integration works well (I've set this up and it's not too hard for admins) and H5P.com also provides some data and metrics not available with just the Moodle plugin or the new H5P core in Moodle functionality. I don't believe there is a "one size fits all" answer here. But I look forward to this discussion, because it will help organisations and administrators make the best choice for their organisations right now, with an eye on the future. Stu.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Bernat If you have two icons in the Activity Chooser, one blue colour, and one black colour, it means you have Moodle 3.9 (with H5P in core), and also have the H5P plugin (which was likely there when you were using Moodle 3.8). My advice, and I think we will have more useful opinions as people transition to Moodle 3.9, is to only use one. I've heard about the spinning wheel, which means a resource is not loading. However, I've not experienced this with H5P in Moodle, and not in the Interactive Video. But it's possibly related to the actual file size, the network speed, of the browser.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the summary and suggestions Stuart. Here's my take! First and foremost all these ways of using H5P are positive for both the H5P and Moodle communities, all content creators, educators and ultimately students etc.. because it allows H5P to be used in a variety of ways across numerous platforms not only Moodle and that's important because it is free and open source software like Moodle. However, this Content Bank implementation from Moodle does not seem to be fully in line with H5P's visions to make interactive content accessible to everyone because it has chosen not to implementing the H5P Hub as they designed and how it is implemented in every other platform. Therefore, it's clear that at present, Joubel, is recommending the H5P Plugin over the Core integration because the Core Integration doesn't include the H5P Hub and thus all its features and including its upcoming OER Hub integration and is not not maintained by H5P. It seems like the Content Bank solution was not done collaboratively with Joubel which is disappointing. Though, I hope this will not mean that Moodle go its own way and that the H5P OER Hub will be integrated within the next release of Moodle. Clearly though, the Core integration as it functions now using the Content Bank still works well, on the Moodle side, for creating and managing H5Ps because you can insert H5Ps from virtually anywhere you can find the Atto editor. Also, the ability to use the alias/shortcut feature to link to H5Ps within your course and or across your site is a really nice and of course the other integrations such as grades and activity completion are too. So, for me to get the best of both worlds would be for Moodle to include the H5P hub natively from H5P. But all that said, I would say the best option is using H5P.com for the¬† reasons listed above but mainly¬† for its premium hosting and LTI platform integrations just to mention a couple. But I will leave it there for now. Regards, Ben

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for posting Ben, and expanding on this conversation. I think you are correct, that there is a political dynamic here. " Moodle does not seem to be fully in line with H5P's visions to make interactive content accessible to everyone because it has chosen not to implementing the H5P Hub " H5P have a fundamental strategy to enable sharing of content, and the H5P OER Hub is central to H5P. Moodle also has a similar aim, to make course sharing possible, through MoodleNet . Although there are differences in intentions, it's clear that at some level these two 'sharing standards' are competitive. I believe there will be some Moodle Net sites that will be really productive and positive. But I think the H5P standard, which can work across many Learning Management Systems, WordPress, Drupal, etc. is fundamentally a more portable and sharable format (similar to SCORM in some ways). So, to some extent, it may depend on the 'integration mention' of the Moodle site as to whether the core H5P functions, or the H5P plugin, would be the best option. However, given that every new Moodle installation will have the H5P core functions, I expect 99% of people will use the H5P core functions out of the box, and miss out on the H5P OER Hub possibilities - until if/when Moodle HQ integrate this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stuart, Ben and all, For the H5P integration in Moodle we set out to find a tighter integration which has resulted in some of the benefits mentioned above. Needless to say this has not been a trivial task and we've taken an iterative approach - starting in 3.8 and with more work completed in 3.9. We have been working with Joubel as much as possible during the process. Of course, at the same time both platforms evolve and Joubel is moving forward with their vision of the HUB, just as Moodle is working on other aspects of our platform. We will be considering how to incorporate the Hub within Moodle's H5P integration - it's something that requires a bit more thought. I'd be keen to hear people's ideas on this. With regards to MoodleNet ; it has a broader view of educators sharing any OER content and curating collections of high quality resources. This could even include H5P and potentially there is an integration pathway between the H5P hub and MoodleNet. At the same time the team is working towards the UX improvements for 4.0 - I hope within that we can also deliver some further improvements for the H5P integration. I'd love to do everything, but we do have to make choices where we focus our efforts. In summary; definitely keen to look at best ways to include the H5P hub, at the moment this requires some more thought and feedback. And we have to balance our efforts on the H5P integration with other work on the platform.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Each approach has advantages over the other. In total, I think that moodle's core integration is the winner, currently. Choosing one over the other may depend on what your (long-term) requirements are, however. It's so hard to predict the future ... Obvious plus for moodle's core integration: admins don't need to take care of one extra plugin. The moodle core integration is more versatile when it comes to integration with moodle's gradebook. You can, for instance, set whether to use the first or the latest attempt, an average, the best, etc. The plugin integration will store the latest only. Both solutions keep all attempts in moodle's history, however. Plus for moodle's integration: The default score to scale to is 100 and not 10. The moodle core integration is better in handling H5P libraries. The option to automatically install the latest version via a cron job is particularly neat in my opinion. As far as I know, doing backups of moodle courses works way better using moodle's core integration. People that I have talked to don't like the extra steps involved in H5P creating and adding content via the content bank of moodle's integration. I assume it's a matter of taste and of what you are used to though. Being able to organize content can be useful. Being able to copy existing H5P content and paste it to create a clone of the exercise or to include in as subcontent in other content types is not possible on moodle's integration for some reason. A feature that I think is not yet supported in moodle's core integration is resuming tasks - called "save content state" in the options of the H5P plugin where it can be activated. If I am not mistaken, only the H5P plugin has a dedicated development mode that allows to patch H5P content types easily if you want to/need to. Since the moodle core integration does not use the H5P Hub, users cannot use the H5P OER Hub which is a global repository of openly shared content that people can use, reuse and contribute to. That's really a nice feature. The moodle team has, however, not ruled out to use the H5P Hub in some way in the future. Having the H5P Hub (or some replacement) will eventually be important, because it is planned to use it more extensively for other things, too, e. g. for adding subcontent to compound content types like Course Presentation. If the H5P Hub is not supported, then it might become impossible to use compound content types like Course Presentation or Interactive Video in the future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for¬† this detailed & useful comparison, Oliver. 1. "Being able to copy existing H5P content and paste it to create a clone of the exercise or to include in as subcontent in other content types is not possible on moodle's integration for some reason." It's still possible to do that, but in a more convoluted way than the "normal" one. Here is a comparison: with the H5P plugin view existing content "H5P my exercise" click Reuse Select Copy content Add content Interactive content Under the "Select content type" title, from Create Content / Upload / Paste select Paste ... et voila! with the H5P integrated activity In the Content bank Select and Edit an existing content "H5P my exercise" At the top right, click the Copy (Copy H5P content to the clipboard) button Exit content "H5P my exercise" In the content bank, click the Add button and from the dropdown list choose any content type, I suggest the very first one, which usually is Accordion In Edit mode for Accordion, Click the Paste and replace button in the top right corner ... et voila! 2.- "A feature that I think is not yet supported in moodle's core integration is resuming tasks - called "save content state" in the options of the H5P plugin where it can be activated." That's correct, and IMHO this is a pity, since the "save content state" option is a vital feature for those H5P activities which should allow the student to quit an un-finished state and come back to it later on, e.g. Dialog Cards. 3.- "The moodle core integration is more versatile when it comes to integration with moodle's gradebook." Yes, that is a strong point of the core integration. The integrated H5P activity also allows more detailed attempts results to be displayed, when several attempts are allowed. 4.- IMHO, in order to avoid confusion in the end-user (teacher) a Moodle site admin should probably not enable both the H5P plugin and the integrated H5P activity on a Moodle site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jean-Pierre, I just wanted to comment here after using Moodle's implementation of H5P for the past 1.5 years. There are a number of limitations and caveats. The first one, I did mentioned in an earlier post that this implementation doesn't take advantage of the H5P Hub which now includes the sharing of H5P globally. Here are my other observations - my day-to-day practical take on using H5P in the Content Bank. No sitewide centralised Content Bank to develop and share H5Ps (i.e. no collaboration and sharing). I think the Admin has this feature/functionality, with a Content Bank site wide but other uses don't and I am not aware of the ability to change this in the settings. While the idea of a course context for creating H5P seems good but ultimately you are working in silos. It is very unproductive to have to download or export H5P in to multiple other courses many times when you want to share content across courses.¬† Sharing of H5Ps is one of the cornerstones of the technology but unfortunately in Moodle is it not the case. The lack of a H5P Hub for sharing is a real shame. Also there is no way to collaborate with colleagues unless you are working in the same course. Because what I am finding is teachers/ed designers in other teaching areas are developing similar content without any knowledge of this happening and this is partly due to the fact that there is no central place to develop H5P sitewide and manage content with other people. Duplication of content because of above & bloat in LMS over time It is not uncommon to me to have 20 plus H5P activities in a single course these days the more I create and use H5P activities. The duplicate is just ridiculous and clearly not an efficient way to manage this content. This is strong argument for hosting your organisations H5Ps externally and using LTI to bring in your content in to your LMS. Creating H5P in the Content Bank is not an intuitive way to develop. Here I want to mention that fact that every other activity you create in Moodle starts with creating an activity or resource then when choosing that activity, it opens immediately for you to create. This is an exception and is not the workflow for creating H5Ps using Moodle's implementation. You are can't create a H5P when "creating" an activity, you are only 'adding' a H5P, that you have already created to the activity. Documentation Tool does not have the 'save the state' function . I can't really use or recommend using the Documentation Tool in Moodle because it doesn't allow for saving the work of your users as you write text into fields. This might be changing and pls anyone who knows comment here. Also this limitation may affect other content types but that have text inputs but I can't be sure. I hope that gives you some ideas of what you will have to contend with using Moodle implementation of H5P but I am sure you will cope. It is just not ideal and there is room for improvements. Best regards, Ben

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: To share the experience of 4 different organisation in different Moodle versions: h5p core in M3.9 - M4.0 Switching from H5P black to blue - Manage content types as a teacher organisations that are switching from black to blue, are obvious compairing the two. reason for switchting was: creating an effective workflow proces in creating,reviewing, releasing and evaluating content - main painpoints where: Course Resetting did not clear the 'save content state' + attempts of students in H5P. Making small changes like an image or text could not managed well between courses. They re-used alot of the content in different courses, so the smallest change (like a typo) needed to be done in every single activity and course where this content was present. They work with contenttype templates for the employees that placed content in, duplicating and coping in the black H5P seemed time consuming. Switching to the blue h5P made it easier for them to manage their content. They solved issues in a pragmatical way, and looking forward to upgrade to the latest version to experience the improved searching in the content bank. Of course they also mentioned pain points: They had prefered that the could build their own folder system in the content bank, and managing the "access" instead of following the Moodle structure. They solved this issue by creating "content bank courses" if you use a non boost theme (prio to 4.0) you had no way to navigate to the contentbank since there is no link in the administration block to the content bank. We encountered various bugs in contenttypes due to not updated PHP files in Moodle 3.9, these won't be fixed until they move to m4.1 - we had to find 'smart' work around to avoid this. There is no Save content state, which gave 'complains' from students because they don't see if they have went through the content. Summary : The new contentbank prevents a¬† painfull proces of clicking and going through courses to by example replace an image, or correct a type. Reviewers responded postive because they where no sure that they just have to check on 1 place. Course builders found that it saved time because now they did not had to use the import functionality to pull out the contenttypes. Working with 'templates' became easier. They would had like the save content state in H5P core BUT also point out that this should work with Course Reset.¬† ¬†( https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-67789 ) H5P core for new users new users need to be explained carefully on how to use the content bank. It is already a 'steap' learning curve on finding your way in Moodle, and the way the content bank works feels counter initituive. This is until they start to realize that the content bank gives them the flexibility and much easier use to add content typesto the Moodle Book, Lesson , Page - we even find them as part of Quiz questions. As siteadministrators and implementors we realized very quickly that with the way the content bank works now, teacher/content creators that start are more aware of the fact that h5P is met to be an 'interactive addition to your content' and not ment to be for quizing or anything formal in reporting. View as a site admin Postive: we saw a reduction in using the H5P activitity, more and more contenttypes where appearing as 'embedded' items in other Moodle activities like pages, books and even part of quiz questions. Positive: a more effective workflow proces goal was achived. Needs investigation:¬†¬†how the cron taks that pulls in new updates of contenttypes works vs the way we update in H5P black. Where we not only updated the contenttype, but also had the option to see 'upgrade' created contenttypes. Concern: within 1 year of implementaton the hvp_xapi_result table in the database is 3x large then the question attempts, current size: 144GB. We do worry that there is no simple way to 'clean' this data. We would had loved an option (like with the logstore) to say we only want to save this data for by example 6 months or 1 year on a sitelevel from a GDPR point of view. Concern: implementing Save content state in H5P core integration Will the option to 'remove attempts' will be forgotten to add to the course reset? And how will this be implementated, as an option or 'as is'. In the latter we will find ourselves again searching for a work around. Concern: how will Moodle HQ deal with 'regressions' due to an update H5P framework handler in still supported versions of Moodle. I might bump into more things, and will added in a later time, noting the time / date of the change. Gemma PS: we also have organisations that build their content in Lumi to avoid unnecessary access to Moodle. They send the file to the organisation, so they can upload it either in the contentbank/H5P activity and have full control of maintaining the content themselves.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Things are getting complicated. There are two things under discussions, as you've broken them in to two paras: Para 1. The recent (1-2 years) changes in the H5P landscape related to Moodle I have no clue. Asking me what I believe won't produce anything. Please note that I haven't made any statements for the simple reason above. I was quoting what I saw in other places. That doesn't mean I believe them or endorse in any way. As already explained, it is (they are) meant as questions asking for the learned audience here for corrections, if anything in those is wrong. From your and Joseph's counter questions, I believe they contain wrong information. It would be great if you and others explain what exactly is wrong and provide the correct answers. Para 2. "policy changes" in H5P as compared to Moodle Lets take the case of a DIY Moodle site. From its beginning, over two decades ago until today, Moodle is Free and Open Source Software in two parts, the Moodle core and plug-ins. Other than the pertubation we had in going from GPL 2 to GPL 3 nothing has changed. I said DIY Moodle to exclude the official service providers, specifically Moodle Partners and the Moodle Cloud. Apparently H5P was different. There was (is) the org and the com. Both hosted H5P content(?), or was it com that hosted, org combined with the H5P plug-in allowed the sites to store content locally(?) Those policies have been evolving, it sounds. Unlike the FOSS Moodle software the user can not avoid following those changes. I know, the comparison is not fair, Moodle for DIY is only software, H5P is software and the produced content which are not necessariy hosted in the server like the common Moodle content. I am not complaining. The H5P creators must have their reasons, e.g. end of funding. AFAIC they are dedicated to the spirit of FOSS. But the user, I believe it is not only me, is confronted with those changes. So it is important to keep this thread, "Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?" alive. I think, it was pinned to the top some years ago - now no more. My posts here also serve as "pings" to keep the thread afloat. It would have been ideal, if that wasn't necessary. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I understand the basic comment here. For many years, in fact as long as Moodle has existed, the "policy" and perspective was always, and excuse my paraphrasing: "Moodle is open source, and so the strategy is to make it as open as possible , using API's etc. to ensure it has interoperability with any external systems." Think: a) Support for SCORM b) Support for payment systems c) API'S / LTI to allow for Turnitin plagiarism detection, etc. etc. H5P was treated fundamentally differently by Moodle HQ when the decision was made for Moodle developers to integrate, and therefore maintain, it's own version of H5P within Moodle. We have then had many years of ordinary teachers confused by the presence of two H5P activities when the plugin was installed (!) and it's not the job of an average teacher to try and understand the pro's and con's of each, and make complex decisions about this. And the whole H5P file picker / repository idea has many frustrated comments from teachers in the forums here. Moodle HQ did some good work in creating the conversion process, so content created by H5P plugin could be changed to H5P Moodle native. But of course the more recent sale of H5P to a completing LMS provider is worrying. It's quite possible that H5P will develop in a way that is not optimum for Moodle. It's also possible H5P will try really hard to ensure it works with Moodle - as the most popular FOSS LMS. I don't know their strategy. But personally, I believe the sensible solution is probably to remove H5P from core, and reply on an official H5P plugin. ¬†There could be a script to convert from Moodle HQ to convert 'core H5P objects' to H5P plugin objects. And then, there is one H5P activity, it's optional, like any other plugin / integration , and it adhere's to the long-held and default Moodle mantra of "build Moodle as easy to integrate with other systems" It's a somewhat complex position we are in now. But I don't believe it should be allowed to continue, and someone, somewhere, should be making a strong high-level decision - with input from relevant stakeholders. But it's above my pay grade Stu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Should you use the H5P plugin, or H5P core functionality in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh boy. To be clear: I do fully understand that one might worry about the future of H5P, but connecting this anxiety to the video that you linked to is absolutely unjustified. That video claims that in 2023 H5P Group had changed a policy regarding h5p.org. The video also claims you were supposed to be able to store your content, but that is said to have changed and that you now had to host things yourself, e.g. on Moodle. The video even speaks of a "free hosting service" (2:30). The whole premise is wrong! The site h5p.org was never ever intended to be a place where you could create and host all your content for your courses. Whenever you created content on that site, you saw this box on top of the editor: Hard to misunderstand, at least in my humble opinion. But let's dig a little deeper, maybe back to 2018? During the Easter time, the h5p.org shut down because it simply could not cope with all the load that people generated by creating and storing their contents their - not for testing, but for production. There's a whole blog post by Joubel on that topic: "H5P.org Easter outage" . To quote from one paragraph: H5P is currently designed exclusively for self hosting. H5P.org was never meant to be a free service for creating and embedding H5P content on external web sites. We are however aware that many uses H5P.org this way, and for those that rely on H5P.org, especially for embedded content, we are incredibly sorry for this service outage. In other words: Despite h5p.org not being meant for hosting your content, people did and Joubel not only tolerated that, but excused for the outage and paid better servers out of their own pockets. H5P.com was introduced in 2018 as well, and that free 30 day testing period on H5P.com was introduced quite soon after. So, I really do not understand what policy that video thinks it is addressing or what is supposed to have changed late in 2023. All the source code of H5P's core, of the content types and of the various H5P integrations has remained openly licensed, has been maintained and improved since then. Summarizing: H5P.org was NEVER a free hosting service for your content. H5P.com did NOT change the open source nature of the H5P project. If you just wanted to discuss some issue that you may have with H5P regarding its licensing, strategic roadmap or whatever - which is totally valid - why would you merely post a more than general question "Evolving more and more..?" and complement it with that bogus video?

ResponsesInList.Title: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodle Community, We want to inform you about a critical update regarding H5P content types. Recently, H5P has updated the versions of most of their content types, including an update to the CKEditor. As a result, these content types will stop working unless you upgrade your Moodle sites to the upcoming releases for versions 4.3, 4.4, and 4.5, which are scheduled to be released on October 7th 2024 . Recommendations : All Moodle instances should disable the ‚Äú Download available H5P content types from h5p.org‚Äù scheduled task until you either upgrade your Moodle version or install the upcoming plugin. Plan your upgrades accordingly to ensure a smooth transition and continued functionality of your H5P content. For Moodle 4.2 instances, a plugin will be released soon to upgrade the H5P libraries. However, please note that there are currently no plans to fix or backport this update to Moodle 4.1, as it involves core changes. For more detailed information, please refer to the issue tracker: MDL-83268 (thanks Gemma for raising it!! üòò). Thank you for your attention to this matter. Best regards, Sara

ResponsesInList.Title: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Sara for reporting this. I reached this post from the Moodle Dev Chat (hopefully). We are using Moodle 4.1, so we are in the worst situation from your post. I kindly ask you if it could be possible to have some forum for news like this, that are applicable to any Moodle instance. Why am I asking this? To improve important communications like this to the whole Moodle community of users with any role. In my case, I am not subscribed to this "H5P" forum, so I were completely unaware. Probably, we would face this problem in our production site unexpectedly. Therefore, a forum for this kind of news, similar in essence to that of "Security announcements", but for other kind of generally applicable issues to any Moodle site, would be very welcome. After that, we could always reply to any other forum (like this "H5P" forum) with the link to the issue in the "general forum". We then would be able to be subscribed and get alerted from any incoming issue. As a proposal for the new forum, it could be named like "Issues with broad affectation" or similar, and without overlapping at all to the "Security announcements". Maybe this forum already exists and I am unaware. Thank you so much for your great work and complete reporting.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: I wanted to clarify that my reported issue was not due to an update of the content type library while H5P core did not support version 1.27. I manage several Moodle sites that are not yet on version 1.26, and so far, I have not encountered any issues, and I am doubtfull if that even will happend but even I will surely disable the automatic task. From my perspective, it seems that the challenge only arises when H5P content is created on a third-party platform with a more recent API version and is then uploaded into Moodle. In this particular case, the content was created in WordPress. Having encountered a similar situation before, I knew exactly what to report. I also noticed that the H5P Plugin version was updated on September 13th, which prompted me to share this information with Moodle HQ to help ensure Moodle‚Äôs H5P core continues to function seamlessly. This all said - while I believe this isn't directly a Moodle-related issue, my reasoning comes from another case we encountered this week that mirrors this issue, though the notification appeared in reverse. In this instance, a teacher had used the CoursePresentation content in the H5P Plugin (not core) and attempted to copy/paste it into the Interactive Book (also using the H5P Plugin). The notification indicated that CoursePresentation supported a higher API version than Interactive Book. But it would be great if there is a different way of handeling thise API Version upgrade from H5P within Moodle H5P core, so that admins can easily switch. Gemma

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: That "reverse" case is nothing dangerous in contrast to the issue at hand which potentially can be. It is also not related to the version of H5P core. In general, if a compound content type expects a subcontent to be using library version X, you cannot put subcontent of library version Y in. We get three cases which should have this behavior: X = Y The content from the clipboard can be pasted without any issue. X > Y Should yield the message: "The content in the H5P clipboard is of a lower version $Y than what is supported in this context ($X), if possible try to have the content you want to paste upgraded, copy it again and try pasting it here." The content from the clipboard (local storage to be precise) was created with an older version of the content type than expected. The content that's in the clipboard/local storage must come from a content on the platform, so that content would need to be upgraded to the version that is required by the parent content (cmp. H5P and not upgrading existing content?! and https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70918 ) before it can be pasted. This case could in theory be covered by automatically upgrading the content as it will when you upload it to the platform. That's not done in H5P core (yet), however. X < Y Should yield the message: "The content in the H5P clipboard is of a higher version ($Y) than what is supported in this context ($X), if possible try to have this content upgraded first, and then try pasting the content here again." The content from the clipboard (local storage to be precise) was created with a newer version of the content type than expected. The message is a little ambiguous: Here "have this content upgraded" refers to the parent content, not the one to be pasted. Hopefully, there already is a version of the parent content type that can host the content that is supposed to be pasted. It would need to be installed on the platform, and the parent content instance would then need to be upgraded (cmp. H5P and not upgrading existing content?! and https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-70918 ). I don't think there's a practical way to resolve this automatically.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Oliver, Thanks for your message! I can confirm that the scheduled task, along with any library updates or content creation using the core H5P integration, are indeed checking the core API and taking no action if the Moodle H5P core version is lower (you can refer to h5p/classes/core.php#L184-L186 for more details). However, as Gemma mentioned in MDL-83268 , a few content types have had incorrect dependencies, leading to some inconsistencies. Fortunately, some of these issues seem to be resolved now. For example, the interactive-book version was updated recently , though verifying this across all possible combinations remains challenging without testing. Additionally, we're encountering issues with the latest version of the third-party plugin mod_hvp , particularly when trying to create content like Course Presentations on a vanilla site. Although the necessary libraries are installed, the system still complains that some are missing, causing ongoing difficulties: Given your expertise with H5P, it would be incredibly helpful if you could guide us on where to find detailed information about these core API changes. This would give us a clearer understanding of any remaining H5P content types that could potentially impact Moodle sites. I apologize if my previous message came across as too cautious, but we felt it was better to flag the issue early rather than regret missing something later. Thanks in advance for your support! Sara

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Sarah! I am very glad that I did not understand correctly. Otherwise, I am sure many people would have run into trouble next week. Better safe than sorry! An H5P library that requires a version of H5P core that is not yet available on the platform should not be installable in any way, IMHO . This includes to check for the core API version requirement when a user uploads H5P content, because that may trigger installing newer library versions from the file . The same goes for installing a library directly, of course.¬†I'd even extend that rule to users with an admin role or at least warn them in that case and require them to actively confirm. Having incorrect dependencies is something that can mess up your day easily, but first and foremost that's the content type maintainers' responsibility, of course. Example: We could assume that H5P.Column had dependencies to H5P.CoursePresentation 1.0 and to H5P.TrueFalse 1.3. That version of Course Presentation could have a dependency to H5P.TrueFalse 1.2. There would be two different versions required for a True False Question. If an author put a True False 1.3¬† into a Column and a Course Presentation that included a True False Question 1.2, that could cause trouble - H5P cannot handle two versions of a library at a time. The dependency of Course Presentation to True False Question would need to be updated to 1.3, in turn the minor version of Course Presentation would need to be bumped, then the dependency from Column to Course Presentation would need to be updated accordingly, and then, finally, the minor version of Column would also need to be bumped. Sounds confusing? It is. It's hardly possible to keep track of all the dependencies manually. That is why the H5P CLI tool has a `h5p utils find-inconsistencies` command. It will check the dependency tree of H5P libraries for conflicting dependencies that would cause trouble. I'd assume the release manager of H5P Group run this check when releasing (or some automated process to be in place), but I don't know. Also, I believe that the command does not check the coreAPI dependencies (yet?). Here, in the dependency tree, no leaf node would be allowed to require a higher version of H5P core than it's parent node. I'd assume that's why recently all (or close to all?) content types have seen an update of the coreAPI dependency regardless of whether they required it themselves directly or not. So, in theory you could integrate something similar into moodle core: a dependency checker that runs whenever an H5P library is about to be installed in order to detect those kind of inconsistencies that may have been introduced out of your control. I think this would rather be suited for being included in H5P core though. Makes more sense to have it in there, doesn't it? Guess that might be worth a feature/pull request. The issues that sometimes occur with the plugin when trying to install/update content types via the H5P content type hub are not limited to moodle.¬† They are a general problem with the H5P content type hub. It does not serve all versions of content types ever created separately, but uses pre-built packages (POST api.h5p.org/v1/content-types/H5P.CoursePresentation for instance will get you the package of the latest version of Course Presentation). If the package is not packed properly, then something like this may happen. This takes place on H5P Group's server , however. They would need to bullet-proof their processes. There's nothing that a client could (sensibly, there's a hack-ish way) do here. As for the H5P core API changes: Unfortunately, there's no information at all. No change log, no info to external developers on upcoming versions, no nothing. Yes, that's bad! Unless something changes or you take action to ask for changes and are successful, you would need to monitor the repositories of H5P core to anticipate a new release. As a heads-up maybe: It's possible that the upcoming theming feature for H5P will lead to version 1.28 and in that case, many content types will see an update of their coreApi dependency as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Important update: H5P content types version bump - Recommendations to avoid issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone! We appreciate all your contributions and questions. Here is an update on the current situation. Thank you for your understanding and patience. Update on H5P content types We've prepared a plugin (h5plib_v127) , that has already been approved in the Moodle directory (thanks, Mikel and Helen!). This plugin can be installed from Moodle 4.2 onwards. Versions 4.5, 4.4.4, and 4.3.8, which will be released on October 7, will include this plugin by default. Some clarifications: Based on our tests, we believe no Moodle site (regardless of version) should be broken, even if the scheduled task is not disabled. There are/were some inconsistencies with the libraries (for instance, with Course presentation ), but we believe they shouldn‚Äôt have an impact. However, we still recommend keeping the scheduled task disabled (at least this month), to confirm everything is OK. Regarding Moodle 4.1 (which uses h5plib_v124 and cannot be upgraded to h5plib_v126 or h5plib_v127 because it needs changes in core): Users will not be able to import H5P content created in h5p.com or higher Moodle versions. That's not new (although until now, only a few content types were affected). Most H5P content types won't be upgraded, so users won't benefit from improvements like the new CKEditor. However, they still be able to use, edit and create the content with old H5P content-type versions.

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P Forum - please read this BEFORE posting
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are asking a question about H5P in this forum it is important that you state the following at the start of your post. If you do not, then it may be impossible for others to answer or assist: Does your query relate to the H5P core activity (the Blue icon), or the H5P plugin (the Black icon identified as Interactive Content). ¬†See the image below. This is a vital difference, because they do not work in exactly the same way. What version of Moodle are you using? This is also vital because the version of Moodle, and therefore the H5P activity, and plugin functionality, can be different. If you do not know the version of Moodle you are using please just ask your IT or Moodle administrator first, and they can let you know. Providing this basic information will mean you are more likely to get helpful answers, and others reading the discussions will also understand if the information is relevant to their own environment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P Forum - please read this BEFORE posting
ResponsesInList.Text: This post is vital, because it is not uncommon that people do not know that there are two different H5P integrations in the first place - but that is quite understandable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Customization of H5P Plugin?
ResponsesInList.Text: Good day all, My organization is using the Branching Scenario H5P Object from the plugin to develop training for our employees.¬† I've gotten some feedback from our training organizers that they would like to change the appearance of the H5P object, things like text size or color and image backgrounds. What would I need to do to enable this customization?¬† Is there a way I can access something like a CSS file or would I need a specialized plugin to have access to changing the visual style?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization of H5P Plugin?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Drew, The ability to customize the appearance of H5P activities in Moodle depends on the version of Moodle you are using and the active theme. Moodle 4.5 and later versions allow direct access to the CSS of H5P activities through the administration interface, enabling style customizations without altering the source code. For earlier versions of Moodle, this functionality is not natively available. In such cases, using a theme like Boost Union is a viable solution, as it provides the capability to inject custom CSS specifically for H5P content, offering flexibility in style adjustments. If neither the Moodle version nor the theme supports direct CSS modifications, the ultimate solution is to alter the CSS of the H5P activity directly within its codebase. This involves modifying the CSS files within the specific H5P library, typically located in the plugin directories on your Moodle server , such as `/moodledata/h5p/libraries/branching-scenario` . While this approach allows for complete customization, it requires caution as updates may overwrite these changes. HTH --C

ResponsesInList.Text: I didn't look carefully it's just core_h5p | h5pcustomcss ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization of H5P Plugin?
ResponsesInList.Text: Contradicting what was written before: You should not alter the original CSS files - or be prepared to do this over and over whenever you install an update of the respective library, because those will override your changes. I am not even mentioning potential side effects that you may cause for others when sharing content. Please, just don't do it. H5P provides different hooks for customizing semantics (options available in the editor), for adding your own JavaScript to the content type context , and for altering the visual appearance by adding your own CSS. This has been possible with the H5P plugin for moodle right from the start (see the official documentation btw : https://h5p.org/node/2692 ), and moodle's own H5P integration in moodle core also has been supporting this for quite a while. The latter also offers a large text field for adding your custom CSS in the H5P settings within the site administration.

ResponsesInList.Title: h5p Module not displaying correctly
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gus, I would suspect that if some content types are not showing that they may not be installed on the system. Supported content types are installed for mod_hvp and the Moodle implementation independently. The Moodle implementation normally installs content types with a scheduled task. Check that that task has run successfully recently. You can also check or upload content types on an admin settings page (General -> H5P -> Manage H5P content types). Daniel

ResponsesInList.Title: Fatal error with h5pactivity_page_type_list() on Moodle 4.5 using h5plib_v127
ResponsesInList.Text: To clarify what may be happening. PHP deprecated implicit nullable parameters in 8.4 and removed them in 8.5. So that the problem may occur if you are running Moodle 4.5 with PHP 8.4 and debugging turned on or in with PHP 8.5. It is probably not a good reason to either of those on a production Moodle 4.5 site. MDL-86822 fixes more recent Moodle versions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P interactive video not working.
ResponsesInList.Text: H5P.Interactive Video ships with a CSS file that's located inside the content type's directory at the relative path `dist/h5p-interactive-video.css`. That won't help much though, because that file is stored within moodle's storage solution and you'd need to use moodle's FileAPI to find it. Moodle is usually configured to bundle assets first and to then send one large (CSS) file to the browser instead of sending multiple small ones, so again, you most likely will not find that file being accessed (and not found) via the network tab of your browser or similar. That's why I suspect that someone would need to investigate this on your server directly. Since some videos are working and some are not, my best guess would be that these are using different versions of H5P.InteractiveVideo and that for one of the versions the CSS file was not installed correctly. That version should be reinstalled to be sure.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P interactive video not working.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P interactive video not working.
ResponsesInList.Text: As I said: You should ensure that the libraries are all installed correctly, re-install them if necessary. If you're using the H5P plugin for Moodle, you'd temporarily (!) set it into development mode by adding `$CFG->mod_hvp_dev = 1;` to your configuration file and by then uploading the demo content of Interactive Video from https://h5p.org/interactive-video as if your wanted to re-use it. That will install the libraries again. This will only help, however, if the latest version of InteractiveVideo is the one that's causing trouble. If it's an older one, you may need to find a file with that one. If you're using Moodle's own H5P integration that is in Moodle core, then I don't know if there's a way to re-install libraries.

ResponsesInList.Text: What is the contenthash value in mdl_filed used for? Is it a key for a file path that's generated, pointing to the original file to be used? If so, I think your suggestion is not bullet proof. You'd then have linked two different H5P integrations together which normally work fully independently from one another. Changes to Moodle's own H5P integration would suddenly be able to influence the H5P plugin - both integrations do not necessarily rely on identical JavaScript files. In turn, this could lead to other issues when updates to the VerticalTabs widget get released.

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity Completion Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: The way that I would go about this, is add the video using the 'h5p interactive video' element - I would add an interaction at the end of the video which asks a question. This could be asking them something factual from the video (with an identified correct answer), or this could be a question along the lines of - 'having watched the video, are you ready to move onto the quiz' (where yes = correct, no = incorrect) You then have the necessary information to check 'completion' - which is then used to make the quiz activity available. An alternative (and less good) way of doing this, is to make the quiz available but not shown on the course page, you then (again using h5p interactive video) add a summary screen which includes the link to the quiz. I have done this with a client who specifically wanted this, but this isn't great for the person to revisit the quiz in the future, and if you create a new course based on this one, you would have to remember to go into the H5p to update the link to the quiz.

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P Content Display Issues After mod_hvp to mod_h5pactivity Migration - Constructor Errors
ResponsesInList.Text: Message: Hi everyone, I hope it's appropriate to post this here. We're experiencing significant problems after migrating from mod_hvp to mod_h5pactivity that seem related to the version bump issues discussed in this forum. Our Environment: - Moodle 4.5.1+ (Build: 20250109) - Successfully migrated using the official " Migrate content from mod_hvp to mod_h5pactivity" tool Migration Journey & Current Issues: We originally had problems with missing icons and input box borders in mod_hvp, so we decided to use the migration plugin hoping it would solve these visual issues. 1. Initial Problem: After migration, H5P uploads showed infinite loading icons - couldn't create new activities or access content bank - Solved: Deactivating WIRIS plugin resolved the upload issues 2. Current Major Problems: - Many migrated activities don't display at all - just blank pages where content should appear (like Interactive Books that show nothing) - Browser console shows: Unable to find constructor for: H5P.Column 1.18 - Visual/styling issues with content that does load - the original missing icons and input box border problems persist, plus general styling inconsistencies Technical Analysis: Looking at the database and content JSON , we found library version mismatches: - Content JSON contains hardcoded references to "H5P.Column 1.13" - Available Column versions: 1.16.2 and 1.18.8 (no 1.13) - JavaScript tries to resolve to "H5P.Column 1.18" but fails to find the constructor Questions: 1. Has anyone experienced similar constructor/library loading issues specifically after hvp‚Üíh5pactivity migration? The migration tool completed successfully, but much of our content is unusable. Our teachers are understandably frustrated with content that worked perfectly before migration (apart from the original styling issues we hoped to fix). Any insights or similar experiences would be greatly appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P Content Display Issues After mod_hvp to mod_h5pactivity Migration - Constructor Errors
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know what the migration tool does in detail. It's possible that your Interactive Book contents were created with Interactive Book version 1.3 (which depends on Column 1.13) but that the migration does not migrate/copy the dependencies. Then Column 1.13 would be missing, and contents requiring it would fail while others (newer ones) work. On the other hand, that would not explain " Unable to find constructor for: H5P.Column 1.18" - I'd expect 1.13 to appear here. You could try to ensure that all the H5P content type libraries are up to date in both H5P integrations, upgrade your existing content that was created with the plugin, so it uses the latest libraries, and then migrate. That should at least rule out library issues. Missing borders, however, rather sound like CSS customization anyway.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Oliver, Thanks a lot for your reply and suggestions! Unfortunately, we still haven‚Äôt been able to resolve the problem. Here‚Äôs what we tried so far: Deleted all cached libraries and re-uploaded them. Used the H5P CLI tool (h5p-cli) to check for inconsistencies. Cleaned the database tables related to H5P libraries and forced reinstall of all required libraries. The result is that I now have multiple versions of the same library (example: Column 1.13.1, 1.16.2, 1.17.0 ‚Äì screenshot attached). When I try to open certain migrated activities (e.g., Interactive Book), I get errors like the one in the console screenshot (uncaught TypeError, destructured parameter is undefined, and ‚ÄúUnable to find constructor for: H5P.Column 1.18‚Äù). From your reply, I understand that the best path would be to upgrade all content to use the latest library versions before migration. My problem is: we have many courses and a large number of activities, so manually editing and re-saving each one is not really feasible. My question is: Is there a way to trigger this upgrade process for all H5P content in bulk (via CLI or script), so that all existing activities are updated to the latest library versions automatically, instead of having to open them one by one? That would really help us make progress. Thanks again for your help!

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P Content Display Issues After mod_hvp to mod_h5pactivity Migration - Constructor Errors
ResponsesInList.Text: Would be great to know what that "destructured parameter" is that is displayed in the console - did you open the console only after you had tried to run the content? If yes, having it open before should ensure that the parameter is printed properly. I have a hunch - did you by any chance install the latest master branch of H5P.Question from github (?) - but may be something else, too. Having different minor versions of libraries is totally normal if you have contents with different dependencies. But Column 1.18 seems to be missing still, so it cannot be loaded. ResponsesInList.Title: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all I get multiple content types under Installed H5P content types in mysite/h5p/libraries.php (attached). Is it normal? Moodle 4.1 LTS (latest), PHP 8.1

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, this is normal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: And I'm not supposed to delete the old ones. The dustbin is too tempting!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know the inner workings of Moodle's H5P integration, you cannot really delete them as long as they are needed by some content type. And given that Moodle's custom H5P integration lacks a (batch) upgrade feature, it's quite normal that over time you'll collect content type libraries in different versions that are still required by content.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: Thats basically correct. H5P does not do dependency handling very well and one content type might require an older version of a lib than another content type so you MIGHT be able to delete them if you are sure noting in your system is using it but its very hard to be sure.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types
ResponsesInList.Text: To be clear: That's not related to the dependency handling of H5P core, but it's a) either content types that would need to be updated or the b) H5P integration (like Moodle's own H5P integration) that would need to prohibit deleting dependencies that are still used by some other library and to provide a mechanism to batch upgrade old content to newer library versions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types [RESOLVED]
ResponsesInList.Text: RESOLVED Do not delete any of these version types unless you are sure that they are not in use! Note that it is very hard to be sure. Thank you both!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple versions of H5P content types [RESOLVED]
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, but as I mentioned, I don't think you can delete libraries that are still in use. H5P integrations usually do not offer a "delete" button for a library if it is a dependency of some other, and Moodle's own H5P integration seems to allow you deletion, but then restores (?) the library if still required - at least that is the behavior that I observed on the moodle sandbox.

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P attempts report
ResponsesInList.Text: We are using Moodle 4.5. I'm wondering if there are any plans to improve the (core) H5P attempts report page - it would be good if it was more like the quiz attempts page. If there are a large number of users in a course, and a small number of attempts, there seems no way to easily navigate to those attempts. I have courses where there are hundreds of pages of users listed. The quiz attempts page shows only the attempts, rather than all users whether or not they have attempted it. This would be much more useful. We use groups, and for teachers within groups they only see their own groups, so at least for those teachers it is easy to find the attempts. However, the page only tells a teacher how many attempts there are across all users, which is of no interest to them - they want to know how many attempts there are for their own groups. Again, the quiz attempts report does this very well as it states the total number of attempts and also the numbers from the teacher's own groups. It would be great if these features could be added in the future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Interactive Book Height Too Much (due to content table)
ResponsesInList.Text: I've double checked the CSS and it's identical on both versions of Moodle. "Additional HTML" is empty on both instances of Moodle. I've also tested it on 4.4 and it has the same problem. Resizing changes nothing (the proportions remain exactly the same, the amount of white space is the same. Or it gets worse if I make the window too narrow). I'm using the standard Boost theme. The sandbox Moodle yielded the same result: https://imgur.com/a/QrZpD0K I'm guessing it's a compatibility problem with 4.5.3?? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Interactive Book Height Too Much (due to content table)
ResponsesInList.Text: Do you still have this error or is this error still existing? I cannot find a solution .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Interactive Book Height Too Much (due to content table)
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to manually update H5P libraries. You know those separate activity types that you download ? Solution was posted here on their forum: https://h5p.org/node/1526108 " Your content is using InteractiveBook 1.3.5. That version has been outdated since December 2021. The current version is 1.11.3. It's in fact the menu that in your version does not get the `display: none` styling, but that is likely a bug that has been fixed during the last 3 years. All you have to do is to upgrade the content to the newest version. " "I edited the activity and saved it again to update the libraries, and it suddenly displays properly!" So after you update those, don't forget to edit at least 1 thing (change a letter or something) in the activity and save that. This should re-process it with the updated H5P libraries thing and it will display properly.

ResponsesInList.Text: Can anyone recommend a developer to custom mod H5P Course Presentation with the features requested below. An intermediate goal will be to have the features integrated into core? Some money is available. Background : H5P¬†Interactive video can prevent a person from advancing the video to the end. Similarly, the engagement activities can be set to require the learner complete and pass the activity before proceeding. Requested features I can add audio and video to Course Presentation. ResponsesInList.Title: H5P interactive video - submit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, I want the answers after each activity to be submitted directly, without having the need to use a separate submit screen. How can I do this for H5P interactive video? TIA Prasita

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P interactive video - submit
ResponsesInList.Text: You'd need to change the code of Interactive Video, there's no such setting, unfortunately. The downside of this approach would be that you'd get multiple attempts registered inside the gradebook, one for each transmission. The other downsides would be those implied by patching and forking. Note that all involved H5P contents (the main content and its subcontents) send out xAPI statements ("results") individually. The respective H5P integration (e. g. the plugin for Moodle or Moodle's own integration) could pick those up and store them as they see fit, but commonly do not. They only keep track of the main content, which in this case is Interactive Video. In other words: This could also be done by changing the code of the H5P integration (Moodle) without the need to change content types (and would help for some other content types, too). You'd probably have to introduce the concept of preliminary scores though, if Moodle's gradebook (or other host platforms' grade books) don't have that in order to make clear that the user has not completed the exercise. And, of course, there would be some variations, but long story short: You won't make that happen without changing code. Alternative: Use a Learning Record Store instead of Moodle's Gradebook, but that's likely not want you want.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Oliver, I shall experiment with the Learning Record Score to see if it fits the requirement.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P Interactive Video issues: slider and codec
ResponsesInList.Text: The video seems to be served very slowly (or has other general issues on that server ), but the position to seek to needs to have been buffered by the browser or you can't seek. This is not related to H5P. You will experience the same issue when watching the video without H5P, see files-6682f86c548ff.mp4 . I don't own a Mac, but I often read about issues with playing videos on Apple devices. MP4 is only a container format that can contain different audio and video codecs. My best guess is that the Mac/Safari cannot play the video codec that is used for the video. In that case, it's also not an H5P issue - H5P relies on what the browser (via the OS) supports. Please see e.g. https://www.google.com/search?q=mp4+not+playing+on+mac for reports of similar issues.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P Interactive Video issues: slider and codec
ResponsesInList.Text: The partial solution came from Eduardo , right? What about the suggestions from Brett ? I quote them here to avoid the back-and-forth between two threads. That is why it is not a good idea. If you have to do it, like this one where you can't localize the problem to one topic, then pl. at least indicate where the follow-up is === Using the Chrome network inspector it took 8 seconds to load 50mb of the video. From what I can tell H5P doesn't progessively load the video, it loads the whole file which is why seeking doesn't work.¬† This will be due to the web server not understanding "partial content requests".¬† ¬†There is some disucssion in this here ( https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8088364/html5-video-will-not-loop/9549404#9549404 ) I strongly suspect that you have a couple of issues which some changes might help If you dont have direct control over the web servers talk to your provider to ensure that partial content requests are being handled correctly, otherwise investigate this. you bandwidth on your hosting looks to be way too small, you should be able to test this directly by downloading a large file to verify or talk to your hosting provider . The quality of the video may be too high for what you are using it for.¬† Consider reducing its resolution and re encoding it to a lower quality/bandwidth. Reduce the length of the video or break it into several smaller videos. The last 2 will be important if you cant resolve the first 2 === https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=463795#p1862129 Now the direct video www.CASP.ca/ video.mp4 (without the space) is delivered trouble-free, the people here could compare it with the H5P videos you posted in the OP . For example this NS_BINDING_ABORTED doesn't look right. This is what StackOverflow has to say about it: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/704561/ns-binding-aborted-shown-in-firefox-with-httpfox#22013028 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P Interactive Video issues: slider and codec
ResponsesInList.Text: RESOLVED! ISSUE: when you move the slider on interactive video, the video restarts from the beginning. RESOLUTION: the issue is not with Moodle, but with Plesk, and specifically nginx. Moving the slider causes the video player to send html code 206 (Partial content) to the server. However Plesk's nginx.conf file does not recognize code 206, so it restarts the video from the beginning. To fix this, the following lines need to be added to "location /" section location / { proxy_set_header Range $http_range; proxy_set_header If-Range $http_if_range; } This fixes the problem. Plesk might fix this in future releases, but this is the solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 4.4 branching scenario with video (video is flickering/shaking)
ResponsesInList.Text: There was a problem a few versions back, where the 'container' that contained the H5p content was dynamically reacting, so it would load, then resize itself slightly to fit, but that then changed the dimensions, so it resized again - and it basically got into a repeated loop of making itself slightly bigger then slightly smaller which appeared to the user as flickering. If my memory is correct it only did it on certain browsers (sorry I forget which) and it only did when the screen width was within a certain range (e.g. it didn't happen on narrow screens or very wide screens). The solution was to add some CSS to change the way the container behaved - but as this was a few versions back, I no longer have that code, but if you use the inspect tools to inspect the page as it is doing it, you may be able to work out the culprit, and make the necessary tweak to stop it from happening. Apologies for being slightly vague here, but it was 4 or 5 years ago that this happened - I thought it had gone away for ever so didn't keep the code that fixed it.
